To the Editor: After a meeting in Dallas, I must comment on Kathryn Jones's article ''What's Doing in Dallas'' (Sept. 24).

The map accompanying the article shows three of the four gigantic freeways extending indefinitely into the vastness of the Texas plains and enclosing the Big D's ''downtown,'' a roughly 10-by-10-block rectangle. From the 38th floor of my hotel, the view of three of these highways and their intricate interchanges was endlessly fascinating -- the most fascinating thing, in fact, about the city. Within the rectangle, a look from the other side of the hotel revealed city streets strangely devoid of either vehicular or pedestrian traffic.

At the opposite end of downtown from my hotel was the ''entertainment neighborhood'' of about three square blocks, with restaurants, clubs, an outdoor sound stage being loudly used when I was there and an indoor multifloor arcade mostly populated by groups of teenagers. Between these poles were a few more-or-less monumental streetscapes, with a very light scattering of on-street attractions. But just one block south of the monumental area and still well within the downtown rectangle was a long street of dereliction and decay.

Despite a very promising light-rail system centered on the downtown rectangle, one gets the distinct impression that the Dallas downtown, and by extension the whole area, is far beyond any possibility of reurbanization.
But Dallas is not unique. It's as though urbanity has been reduced to a hobby, like classical music, and there are just enough such hobbyists to populate New York and San Francisco.
